Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a theoretical investigation of recently-discovered supernovae with unusual characteristics. New surveys are digging up large numbers of supernovae of all types, and some relatively rare events have now been thoroughly studied. The goal of the project is to see if these supernovae can be explained as resulting from thermonuclear supernovae in which the total mass of the exploded white dwarf does not necessarily equal the maximum allowed (Chandraskehar) mass. The PI will explore double degenerate mergers, helium shell explosions, and accretion induced collapse events, and will compare observations of light curves, spectra, and polarization to the output of models that include sophisticated radiation transport codes.

The project will allow direct comparisons between theory and observation, which will help observers explain new discoveries, and help modelers to stay rooted in actual data. This group will also organize a summer school on high-performance computing, which will draw 50 students. The goal of the school is to give students hands-on experience with production scientific codes, which will help produce the next generation of computational astrophysicists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project has been to better understand the physical nature of certain supernovae that are believed to result from the thermonuclear explosion of compact white dwarf stars. Such events are important as they play a role in the creation of the heavy elements in the universe, may represent the formation of dense objects like neutron stars, and can be used to probe the expansion of the universe. We studied several different phenomena, including what happens when two white dwarfs violently merge, when a white dwarf is tidally squeezed when passing to close to a massive black holes, or when an inflated massive star dies. Our method involved using supercomputers to simulate the hydrodynamics and nucleosynthesis in these explosive environments, and then modeling the light curves, spectra, and polarization of the ejected debris using a radiation transport code. These models were compared to observations of supernovae to better constrain the progenitors and explosion mechanism of the events we see in the sky. Among our main outcomes was to provide evidence that Type Ia supernovae were the result of the explosion of carbon/oxygen white dwarfs, that the companions of several explosions were non-existant or of small radius, that the merger of white dwarfs can lead to peculiarly overluminous "super-Chandrasekhar" mass events, and that newly discovered rapidly fading supernovae may be the result of massive star explosions in inflated stars. The results have helped motivate ongoing and future astronomical experiments, and have facilitated the education and training of students in astrophysics and high performance computing.
